Conclusion
text.101:
In this verse, Allah explains that when the trumpet is blown for the second time and souls are returned to their respective bodies on the Day of Resurrection, there will be no benefit from lineage. A person can no longer boast of their lineage, that they come from noble descent, as they did when they were still in the world. There is no difference between one person and another; all are affected by the atmosphere surrounding them. They are confused and filled with fear because of the awesomeness of that day, so that love and affection disappear. Each person thinks only of themselves and does not want to know about others, as described in Allah's words:

"Then when there comes the Deafening Blast - On the Day a man will flee from his brother, And from his mother and his father, And from his wife and his children, For every man, that Day, will be a matter adequate for him." ('Abasa/80: 33-37)

They no longer greet or ask each other. No one among them asks about the condition of their family and descendants, as they did in the world. They are as if they no longer know each other. Allah says:

"And no friend will ask [anything of] a friend." (al-Ma'arij/70: 10)

They are confused like people who are drunk, even though they are not drunk. Allah says:

"On the Day you see it every nursing mother will be distracted from that [child] she was nursing, and every pregnant woman will abort her pregnancy, and you will see the people [appearing] intoxicated, but they are not intoxicated; but the punishment of Allah is severe." (al-Hajj/22: 2)
text.102:
This verse explains that those whose scales of good deeds are heavy, meaning those who believe and perform many righteous deeds in the world, are the fortunate and happy ones. On the Day of Judgment, before a person's fate is determined, whether they will be admitted to Paradise or Hell, they will first be brought to a court that will render the fairest of judgments. There will be no cheating in the trial process because Allah Himself is the judge. This is different from courts in this world, where a guilty person may sometimes be found not guilty, due to clever rhetoric, twisting the situation, or the cunning of their defense, thus deceiving the judge. Conversely, an innocent person may possibly be found guilty because they cannot afford a clever defender, and so on. Every unfair decision in this world will be overturned and decided again in the hereafter with the utmost fairness. All outstanding matters that have not been resolved in this world will be resolved later in the hereafter with the utmost fairness. After going through the trial process and each person's outstanding matters have been resolved, a weighing will be conducted to determine the measure of each person's good and evil deeds, as explained in Allah's word:

"And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection, so no soul will be treated unjustly at all." (al-Anbiya'/21: 47)

Whoever's scales of good deeds are heavy, then blessed are they. In line with verse 102, Allah says:

"Then as for one whose scales are heavy [with good deeds], He will be in a pleasant life." (al-Qari'ah/101: 6-7)
text.103:
In this verse, Allah explains the loss of those whose scales of good deeds are light. When they were still in the world, they committed many sins, following the desires of their ego. They denied the verses of Allah, which caused their deeds to be worthless in the Hereafter, as Allah says:

"Those are the ones who disbelieve in the signs of their Lord and in the meeting with Him (in the Hereafter). So their deeds are in vain, and on the Day of Resurrection, We shall not assign to them any weight." (al-Kahf/18: 105)

They will abide forever in Hell. In line with verse 103, Allah says:

"But as for him whose scales are light (with good deeds), his abode will be Hawiyah (a pit in Hell)." (al-Qari'ah/101: 8-9)

"No! Whoever earns evil and his sin has encompassed him - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein forever." (al-Baqarah/2: 81)
text.104:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who are cast into Hell will have their faces burned by the fire, making them look extremely ugly and deformed. Their flesh will be destroyed, melting down to their feet. They will lament the torment that befalls them, and realize their deeds when they were still in the world, as Allah says:

"And if a breath of the punishment of your Lord touches them, they will surely say, "Woe to us! Indeed, we have been wrongdoers." (al-Anbiya'/21: 46)

If only the disbelievers knew, when they will not be able to ward off the fire from their faces or from their backs, and they will not be helped (they would not have asked for it to be hastened)." (al-Anbiya'/21: 39)
text.105:
In this verse, Allah explains that various mocking questions are posed to the inhabitants of Hell. This reminds them that messengers were sent to guide them, and heavenly books were revealed to be their guidance, so that they would have no excuse for not obeying and adhering to the teachings brought by the messengers, as Allah says:

"So that mankind will have no argument against Allah after the messengers. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise." (an-Nisa'/4: 165)

And His saying:

"And We would never punish until We sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15)

But they denied the verses of Allah and did not believe in them at all, even torturing and persecuting the messengers who were sent to them. In line with verse 105 of this verse, Allah says:

"It almost bursts with rage. Every time a group is cast therein, its keepers will ask them, "Did there not come to you a warner?" They will say, "Yes, a warner did come to us, but we denied and said, 'Allah has not sent down anything. You are not but in great error.'" (al-Mulk/67: 8-9)
text.106:
In this verse, Allah explains the admission of the inhabitants of Hell regarding their misguidance, even though messengers were sent to them to guide them, and heavenly books were revealed to be their guidance. However, they were defeated by their evil deeds and controlled by their desires, so there was no way for them to do good and avoid the path of misguidance. In line with this verse is Allah's saying:

"Then we confessed our sins. So is there any way for us to get out (of Hell)?" (al-Mu'min/40: 11)
text.107: This verse explains the request of the inhabitants of Hell to Allah, which is that they be taken out of Hell and returned to the world. They promise that if their request is granted, they will change their disbelief into faith and obey all that Allah has commanded them. If they still continue to commit disobedience as they did before, then they are truly wrongdoers and they deserve to receive a most painful torment and punishment.
text.108: This verse explains Allah's response to the request of the inhabitants of Hell to be returned to the world to atone for the mistakes and sins they have committed. Allah affirms to them to remain in Hell, cowering in a state of humiliation and having no self-worth whatsoever. They must be silent and not continue their conversation with Allah, nor repeat their actions, because it is no longer possible for them to be returned to the world.
text.109:
In this verse, Allah explains the causes of their torment and punishment, as well as the humiliating answer to their request to return to the world. This humiliation arises because they insulted Allah's servants who had believed, such as Bilal, Khabbab, Shuhaib, and other weak believers, who always drew near to Allah, affirmed their pledge and acknowledgment of faith in Him, declared the truth of the messengers He had sent, and constantly sought forgiveness and implored His mercy, for He is the best of those who show mercy. The disbelievers confronted these believers with mockery, laughter, and contempt. This verse also explains that the preoccupation of the disbelievers was mocking and laughing at the believers, causing them to forget to remember Allah. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"Indeed, the criminals used to laugh at those who believed. And when they passed by them, they would wink at one another. And when they returned to their own people, they would return jesting. And when they saw them, they would say, "Indeed, these are truly lost." But they were not sent as guardians over them." (al-Muthaffifin/83: 29-33)
text.110:

This humiliation arises because they insulted Allah's servants who had believed, such as Bilal, Khabbab, Shuhaib, and other weak believers, who always drew near to Allah, affirmed their pledge and acknowledgment of faith in Him, declared the truthfulness of the messengers He had sent, and constantly sought forgiveness and begged for His mercy because He is the best of those who show mercy. text.111:
This verse affirms that Allah will reward the believers on the Day of Judgment, because of their patience and steadfastness in the face of the mockery and laughter of the disbelievers, as well as their obedience and submission to His commands. Indeed, the believers are the victors and the fortunate ones. In the Hereafter, they will sit on couches, leisurely gazing, laughing at the disbelievers who used to laugh at them in the world. This is the recompense for the disbelievers for what they did in the world, as Allah says:

"So today, those who believed are laughing at the disbelievers, on adorned couches, observing. Have the disbelievers [not] been recompensed [with a reward] for what they used to do?" (al-Muthaffifin/83: 34-36)
text.112: After the request of the inhabitants of hell to be returned to the world was rejected by Allah with the affirmation that they would remain curled up in hell and so that they would not beg of Him, they were asked again how long they lived on earth, from birth until leaving this transient world for the eternal realm.
text.113: Due to the immense impact of the disaster that befalls the inhabitants of hell and the severity of the torment and punishment they endure, those unfortunate souls can no longer remember how long they lived in the world. They feel it was very short, even thinking that they lived in the world for only a day or less than a day when compared to the afterlife. In this verse, Allah encourages them to ask how long they lived in the world.
text.114:
This verse explains that they indeed lived in the world for only a short time. If they had realized this while they were living in the world, while the life they would face in the hereafter is a life without limits, surely they would have done things that were beneficial and in accordance with what Allah commanded. However, they were negligent in realizing this, so they deserved punishment from Allah. The Messenger of Allah said:

When Ibn Abi Hatim narrated from Aiqa' bin Abd al-Kalai, the Messenger of Allah said that when the inhabitants of Paradise have entered Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell have entered Hell; Allah will say, "O inhabitants of Paradise! How long did you live in the world?" They will answer, "We lived in the world for only a day or not even a day." Allah will say, "How good it was for you to invest that one day, or not even one day. You have obtained My mercy, My pleasure, and My Paradise. Dwell in Paradise forever." After that, Allah will say, "O inhabitants of Hell! How long did you live in the world?" They will answer, "We lived in the world for only a day or not even a day." Allah will say, "How bad it was for you to invest that one day or not even one day. You have received My wrath and entered My Hell. Dwell in Hell forever."
text.115:
This verse explains that the denial of the inhabitants of hell regarding the existence of the Day of Resurrection is related to their belief that life ends with death. Therefore, Allah needs to remind them with the question, "Then did you think that We created you uselessly and that to Us you would not be returned?" (al-Mu'minun/23:115). Or do they think that they will be left alone like animals, not rewarded and not punished? No, again no. They were created as servants of Allah and given obligations. Those who fulfill their obligations will be rewarded, and those who neglect their obligations will be punished and returned to Allah to account for all their actions in the world, according to Allah's word:

Does man think that he will be left neglected? (al-Qiyamah/75: 36)
text.116:
This verse explains that Allah is Most Holy from what the polytheists accuse Him of, as well as the assumption that He created mankind in vain, because He is the True God. There is no god but He, the Lord of the Noble 'Arsh (Throne). He is the One who governs this universe, both above and below, as well as all of His creations. Allah says:

And We did not create the heavens and the earth and that between them in play. We did not create them except with haq (truth), but most of them do not know. (ad-Dukhan/44:38-39)
text.117: This verse explains that those who worship Allah and associate partners with Him, even though there is nothing worthy of worship except Allah, in reality have no justification whatsoever for their actions. They will be brought before Allah to be held accountable and responsible for all their deeds. Allah will perfect the recompense for their actions. Indeed, the disbelievers will never prosper and will not escape the torment that afflicts them.
text.118: This verse explains that after clarifying the state of the disbelievers, their ignorance in the world, and the punishment prepared for them in the Hereafter, Allah commands His Messenger to beseech Him for forgiveness for all the mistakes he has made, to be granted mercy by having his repentance accepted, and to be freed from punishment for negligence and errors he has committed, because He is the Bestower of mercy. Allah's command to His Messenger as mentioned above is to be a good example for his ummah. Every time they make a mistake, they should seek forgiveness (istighfar), and every time they commit disobedience, they should quickly repent (taubat), lest those mistakes and disobedience accumulate, because that will become a heavy burden later on the Day of Judgment.
